prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Perseus Binaries
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe dust continuum and molecular lines toward binary protostars in the Perseus molecular cloud.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our overall time estimate is driven by the sensitivity requirement of the C18O (J=2-1) observations, which is 11.8 mJy/beam in a 0.096 km/s velocity channel. This sensitivity will enable us to detect the high-velocity line wings of C18O and 13CO associated with disk rotation out to at least +/- 2 km/s from line center (see Figure 3). The strength of C18O emission will vary between sources, thus we are using ALMA Cycle 0 observations of the sources L1527 and VLA1623 and CARMA observations of L1165 to guide our sensitivity limts. These sources span the luminosity range of our sample, ~1 Lsun for VLA 1623 to 15 Lsun for L1165. We have scaled the expected flux densities to the distance of Perseus (230 pc) and the emission at +/- 2.0 km/s from line center in a given velocity channel is 59 mJy/beam for VLA 1623, 74 mJy/beam for L1527, and 250 mJy/beam for L1165. Thus, we can expect signal-to-noise ratios to range from ~21 to ~5 at +/- 2 km/s from line center; at lower velocities the emission will be stronger, so this lower limit of our expected signal-to-noise in the channel maps. A signal-to-noise ratio >= 5 is necessary to centroid the position of line emission at the high-velocities to an accuracy of ~13 AU; the relative positional accuracy is ~ beam/signal-to-noise (Reid et al. 1988).
The integration time necessary for the line observations will yield a continuum sensitivity of 0.06 mJy with the 2 GHz of bandwidth. This sensitivity is more than enough to detect the individual sources, in addition to an compact circumbinary disk structures. For comparison, the 1.3 mm observations shown in Figure 2 had a sensitivity of 0.6 mJy and detected the circumbinary disk with high confidence. The requested ALMA observations will exceed this sensitivity by a factor of 10, enabling the detection of any compact circumbinary structures with high significance.

We will observe the C18O and 13CO (J=2-1) lines the same base-band, allocating half the correlator resources to each line and observing with a 60 MHz bandwidth, 0.096 km/s velocity resolution. We are also observing the SO (6-5) line, H2CO (3-2), and 13CS (5-4) lines with ~0.096 km/s resolution because they may also trace kinematics on the scale of disks toward the protostellar sources. The line widths are expected to be +/-2 km/s owing to rotation of the protostellar disks; the high spectral resolution is necessary because the position of the line emission changes with velocity and mapping the position-velocity change is crucial to determining if the sources have rotationally-supported circumbinary disks.
We will also observe the 12CO (J=2-1) line with 60 MHz bandwidth and 0.31 km/s channels. The 12CO line is expected to trace the outflow emission and will be spread over a larger velocity range (> +/- 10 km/s) necessitating lower velocity resolution and broader overall bandwidth. We are allocating one baseband to observe the 1.3 mm continuum emission with a total of 2 GHz of bandwidth in order to examine the compact dust emission surrounding the protostars.

Our observations will be conducted at 0.2" resolution in order to resolve the individual proto-binary sources and map kinematics in the protostellar disks. The declination of Perseus is about 31 degrees (max. elevation 36 degrees), casuing the beam to be elongated in the north-south direction yielding 0.35" X 0.2" resolution; this elongation will not affect our ability to resolve the close binary sources. The largest angular scale in the observations will be 3.4", encompassing the entire area shown in Figure 1 subpanels. This is more than enough spatial sensitivity to detect circumbinary structure on the scale of ~780 AU around these sources. The surrounding envelopes will be resolved-out, but this will not affect our science goal of examining the small scale structure directly associated with the protobinary sources. The C18O and 13CO emission that traces disk rotation will be spatially unresolved in the line wings at velocities greater than +/- 0.5 km/s from line center.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The formation of binary and multiple systems is thought to occur during the early stages of the star formation process. The formation mechanism remains unclear, but disk fragmentation or turbulent fragmentation with dynamical evolution are most likely. To understand protostellar multiplicity, we are conducting a VLA 8mm survey of all protostars (N~80) in the Perseus molecular cloud (d=230pc) at 0.065" (15 AU) resolution. We have identified 18 proto-binary systems with separations < 500 AU; 15 are new discoveries. While these detections are significant, the VLA data alone do not convey their formation mechanism. Therefore, we propose to ALMA observations of dust continuum and molecular line emission (C18O, 13CO, CO) toward these 18 sources to characterize their circumbinary environments. We specifically aim to determine whether or not these close multiples have formed within rotationally-supported circumbinary disks, determined via molecular line kinematics. This sample is large enough to reveal whether or not binaries typically form via disk fragmentation or turbulent fragmentation.
***Resubmission of 2013.1.00031.S with one additional source.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00041.S,'Orion Disk and Multiplicity Survey',PI John Tobin 2013.1.00096.S,'Characterizing the Kinematic Structure of VLA-Detected Protostellar Disk Candidates',PI John Tobin
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00031.S,'Are Close Binaries Formed via Disk Fragmentation?',PI John Tobin
